channel.title: Facebook smartphone
channel.description: [font=Helvetica][size=14px]Nick Bilton over at The New York Times technology blog is[/size][/font][font=Helvetica][/size][size=14px] [/size][/font][font=inherit][/size][size=14px]reporting[/size][/font][/color][font=Helvetica][/size][size=14px] [/size][/font][font=Helvetica][/size][size=14px]that Facebook is getting serious about designing and releasing a smartphone. He quotes several anonymous Facebook employees and other Silicon Valley engineers in his report, stating that Facebook hopes to release a smartphone “by next year.”[/size][/font][font=Helvetica][/size][size=14px]Some of the anonymous engineers cited were evidently sought out specifically by Facebook for their expertise with smartphone hardware design. Some of them are or were Apple employees. Facebook has been recruiting individually for the project to keep details from leaking out in job postings. Bilton states that Facebook has already hired “more than half a dozen former Apple software and hardware engineers.”[/size][/font][font=Helvetica][/size][size=14px]It’s easy to see why Facebook would want to move into the mobile hardware business. The company’s [font=inherit]IPO[/font][/size][/font][/color] didn’t go precisely to plan, and now that it has to answer to investors on a quarterly basis, revenue will have to be a major focus. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg told investors that [font=inherit]mobile would be the key[/font] to the company’s future revenue. The recent release of the[font=inherit][/color]Facebook Camera App[/font] for iOS is proof that he meant it. From The New York Times Report:[/color][font=Helvetica][/size][size=14px][i]“Mark is worried that if he doesn’t create a mobile phone in the near future that Facebook will simply become an app on other mobile platforms,” a Facebook employee said.[/i][/size][/font][font=Helvetica][/size][size=14px]Zuckerberg’s fear is well-founded. Facebook will not have the control or amount of integration it wants (especially on iOS) unless it takes charge and creates both the hardware and software for mobile devices. Apple has demonstrated how to make locked-down communities profitable: good marketing and premium pricing. Facebook is on the right track if it’s looking to former Apple employees to help create a smartphone.[/size][/font][font=Helvetica][/size][size=14px]However, the smartphone market is looking pretty crowded these days. RIM is [font=inherit]going down[/font][/size][/font][/color] in flames, and even the Android market is consolidating, being [font=inherit]taken over[/font] by Samsung. Is there really room for another competitor in the smartphone space, even one with as many members as Facebook? Also, does Facebook itself have brand loyalty, or is it simply the place where all of our friends are? We will find out in the coming year. item.title: Facebook smartphone
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Their data only has value as long as Facebook is popular. Google got rich thanks to advertisements, but their ads aren’t limited to their own site, they are a man in the middle. Besides, Google has much more to offer than just advertising. It’s still their cash cow, sure.

Facebooks P/E ratio is around ~60-70 (depending on what the exact profit was in 2011), while that of Google is ‘only’ ~18 and that of Apple ~14 (still high). Facebook had a profit of $1B in 2011, or $0,4677 per share. Assuming Facebook is a bit better than Google and Apple (it isn’t, Apple for instance has a big pile of cash which is a big plus), at a P/E ratio of 20 the price should be $9,36. 68% lower. I’d rather wipe my ass with my money than spend it on Facebook.

(P/E ratio is just one ratio, but I bet other ratio’s will show a similar picture.)

Edit: To clarify, with Facebook being better (and having a fictional P/E of 20) I meant that the prospects of Facebook were better than that of Google and Apple, which justifies a higher price and as a result a higher P/E. Just before the IPO, the expected figures were downgraded so a P/E of >70 is crazy.

I think it’ll flop. If they keep recruiting ‘Apple’ engineers (who cares?) why don’t they just discuss a business deal with Applet that is in Facebook’s interests? I never see Facebook expanding into any other market than where it is now, especially not into the phone market.

They have to spew out ideas now, if they don’t the stock price will plummet. Up until now, Facebook hasn’t been more than a site with a globally known brand name. A company based solely on a brand name is very risky, if popularity drops such a company can go bankrupt in no time.[/quote]spot on
